action: Single-family zone reform strategy (R, SRA, SRB)
description: Comprehensive reform of Portsmouth's three single-family-only zones, which together represent 2,276 acres — 85.8% of all residential land. Only 375 acres (14.2%) currently allow the multifamily housing types most residents can afford. Zone-specific proposals based on GIS analysis of NH State data: R Zone (498 acres, currently 5-acre minimum): reduce to 1-acre minimums, allow two-family by right — potential increase from 41 parcels to 250+ housing units. SRA Zone (589 acres, currently 1-acre minimum): reduce to 15,000 sf minimums, allow two-family and small multifamily — potential 3x density increase while maintaining neighborhood character. SRB Zone (1,189 acres, currently 15,000 sf minimum): reduce to 7,500 sf minimums, allow two-family by right, multifamily by special exception — brings 1,672 undersized parcels into compliance and potentially doubles housing capacity. Additionally, allow ADUs in single-residence zones to use GRA dimensional rules, removing the variance requirement that currently blocks ADU construction on the majority of nonconforming lots.
target: Phase 1: Council workshop presentation of fiscal and compliance data (2026). Phase 2: Draft zone-specific amendments with public input. Phase 3: Planning Board review and Council adoption.
metric: Parcels brought into zoning compliance per zone; net new housing units permitted in reformed zones; tax revenue per acre trend; lot splits and two-family conversions per year.
notes: This addresses the structural gap in the current Housing Committee approach, which has focused on developer incentives and city-owned property partnerships — valuable tools, but they operate within the 14.2% of residential land that already allows multifamily. The 85.8% locked in single-family-only zoning is the largest untapped opportunity for housing production and fiscal sustainability. An additional equity dimension: allowing gentle density through smaller lot sizes and additional units is a potential financial windfall for existing property owners. Portsmouth Listens sessions revealed significant numbers of older homeowners who cannot find ways to downsize given current market constraints. Lot splits and conversion rights would allow these homeowners to leverage existing property investment to facilitate their own downsizing — 'like digging up $500K in the backyard' — while simultaneously increasing housing supply and city tax revenue. The exclusionary history of single-family-only zoning is also relevant: Portsmouth's 85.8% SF-only land allocation closely mirrors the Bay Area's 83% figure documented in UC Berkeley's Othering & Belonging Institute research on the discriminatory origins of single-family zoning.
sources: Byron Matto GIS analysis (Jan 2026); NH State GIS database; 2017 Listens

Brings thousands of legally nonconforming parcels into compliance, expanding options for homeowners seeking to modify or expand their properties.

Reduces per-household infrastructure costs (estimated $44,976 multifamily vs. $51,721 single-family per parcel) — new housing in reformed zones may cost less to serve.

notes: Some protections limited by NH state law NH LEGAL VIABILITY: Under current NH landlord-tenant law (RSA 540), municipalities have limited authority for tenant regulation. Tools that are likely viable: extended notice periods beyond state minimums for lease non-renewals, voluntary landlord incentive programs, source-of-income non-discrimination (if enacted at state level), and relocation assistance funded through housing trust funds. Any tenant protection policy should be reviewed by legal counsel for consistency with RSA 540 and state preemption doctrine.

action: School capacity assessment for housing areas
description: Document existing school capacity data by attendance zone and make it publicly accessible as part of the city's housing data resources. Coordinate with the School Board to ensure capacity documentation aligns with current enrollment trends and projections.
metric: School capacity assessment completed; housing plans aligned Additional metric: Cost of services vs. tax revenue per housing unit — document that net tax revenue generated by new housing units typically exceeds the marginal cost of educating additional students, particularly for smaller multifamily and ADU units that generate fewer school-age children per unit than single-family homes. Cross-reference fiscal impact analysis modules for Portsmouth-specific per-pupil cost data.
sources: HC Work Plan (Corsetti); RKG 2022 (enrollment projections); Byron Matto GIS analysis (Jan 2026)
notes: Colleague feedback: no additional study needed; capacity exists. Reframe toward documenting existing capacity as an advocacy tool. Political note: opponents of new housing rarely argue capacity — they argue cost. The advocacy asset framing should include per-pupil cost data alongside capacity data to preempt the "housing raises school taxes" objection. GIS analysis provides baseline infrastructure cost comparisons: single-family zones require 1.15x more linear infrastructure per parcel (roads, utilities), with estimated costs of $51,721/parcel vs. $44,976 for multifamily. The fiscal sustainability ratio (tax revenue relative to infrastructure burden) is 15.9 for single-family vs. 23.9 for multifamily — meaning multifamily zones are 50% more fiscally efficient to serve.
pros: Publicly documented capacity data enables informed discussion of housing impacts on schools.
School Board coordination ensures housing planning aligns with enrollment trends.
Sherburne School provides a direct precedent for school-to-housing conversion.
Surplus school properties are often well-located in neighborhoods.
cons: Capacity documentation alone doesn't address school quality concerns
Enrollment projections are inherently uncertain — capacity claims may be challenged
School capacity varies by grade level and program — aggregate numbers can be misleading

description: Production targets calibrated by AMI band. RKG projects 52% of demand from households at ≤80% AMI, 85% from 1-2 person households. Total demand: 3,124 units (227 owner, 2,897 renter) by 2030.
target: 52% of new units affordable at ≤80% AMI
metric: Production by AMI band vs. targets; unit size distribution; owner vs. renter mix
sources: RKG 2022 (demand projections by AMI and household size)
notes: The ≤50% AMI segment represents the most severe affordability gap in Portsmouth. While RKG documents 52% of demand at ≤80% AMI overall, the subset at ≤50% AMI faces the most acute shortage — these households cannot be served by market-rate production or moderate-income workforce housing incentives. Production at this level requires deep subsidy (LIHTC, project-based vouchers, public housing). The HAP should explicitly differentiate targets and strategies for ≤50% AMI, 50-80% AMI, and above-80% AMI segments to ensure the lowest-income households are not overlooked in favor of more financially feasible workforce housing.
pros: AMI calibration ensures production targets match the income distribution of demand
RKG data (52% of demand at ≤80% AMI) provides the baseline for calibration
Prevents a scenario where 'housing production' means only luxury units

description: Establish healthy vacancy target (4-6%) and monitor. RKG documents 1.86% combined vacancy — well below functional market threshold.

notes: Scale estimate: Portsmouth has approximately 12,000 housing units. Moving from 1.86% vacancy to a 4% target implies roughly 250+ net new vacant-and-available units. Accounting for absorption (new units that fill immediately) and the relationship between production and vacancy, achieving a functional 4-6% vacancy rate likely requires on the order of 800-1,200+ net new units over the planning horizon — a figure that should be modeled explicitly against production targets and absorption rate assumptions.

action: Planning department capacity and workflow assessment
description: Evaluate planning department workflows to identify process efficiencies — such as expanded administrative approvals, standardized review checklists, digital intake systems, and delegation of routine application processing — that would free professional planning staff to engage in proactive policy development, housing strategy implementation, and long-range planning rather than spending the majority of their time on application processing.

Process reform is the precondition for plan implementation in a budget-constrained environment where additional headcount is unlikely.
pros: Unlocks staff capacity for HAP implementation without new headcount — budget-compatible
Process reforms benefit all applicants, not just housing projects
Directly addresses the implementation bottleneck — without capacity, the HAP sits on a shelf

action: HAP formal adoption and governance framework
description: Establish a formal adoption mechanism for the Housing Action Plan as a binding policy document — not merely advisory. This includes: City Council resolution or ordinance formally adopting the HAP with specific commitments; designation of a lead department (Planning) and responsible staff positions for implementation; establishment of a HAP Implementation Committee with defined membership, meeting schedule, and reporting requirements; and integration of HAP priorities into the city's annual goal-setting and strategic planning processes. Without formal adoption, the HAP risks becoming another advisory document that sits on a shelf.
target: Council adoption within 6 months of HAP completion. Implementation Committee established within 90 days of adoption.
metric: Formal adoption vote (yes/no); Implementation Committee formed and meeting (yes/no); HAP referenced in annual city goals (yes/no).
notes: This is the single most important implementation item. Review 1 identified the absence of binding governance as the brainstorm's most significant structural gap. Without an adoption ordinance and named ownership, 124+ action items become an aspirational catalog rather than a governing framework. The adoption mechanism should specify whether the HAP is a standalone ordinance, a resolution, or an amendment to the Master Plan — each has different legal weight and amendment procedures.
pros: Transforms the HAP from advisory to binding — creates legal and political accountability
Named departmental ownership ensures someone is responsible for driving implementation
Formal adoption gives the HAP standing in budget deliberations and land use decisions
cons: Council may resist binding adoption if it constrains future discretion on individual projects
Formal governance structure adds administrative overhead and meeting obligations
Political risk if Council adopts the HAP but then visibly fails to implement it

description: Establish a quarterly implementation dashboard and annual progress report to City Council tracking HAP action item status, housing production against targets, and resource deployment. Dashboard should be public-facing and include: number of action items advanced per quarter, units permitted and completed by type and affordability level, budget allocated vs. spent on housing initiatives, and comparison to AMI-calibrated production targets. Annual report presented formally to Council with staff recommendations for priority adjustments.
target: Quarterly dashboard operational within 6 months of HAP adoption. First annual report within 12 months.
metric: Dashboard published quarterly (yes/no); annual report presented to Council (yes/no); percentage of HAP action items advanced per year.
notes: Accountability reporting serves two functions: it creates internal pressure for staff to advance HAP items, and it provides advocates with a public record to hold elected officials accountable. The dashboard mockup should be developed before adoption to show Council what accountability looks like — this demonstrates the advocacy's seriousness about implementation, not just planning.
pros: Creates regular, visible accountability that prevents the HAP from being shelved after adoption
Public dashboard builds transparency and resident trust in the housing reform process
Quarterly cadence keeps housing on the Council agenda rather than being a once-a-year topic
cons: Reporting requires staff time to compile data — adds to already-stretched capacity
Public dashboards showing slow progress could be used to criticize the city rather than motivate action
Risk of measuring activity (items advanced) rather than impact (units produced, affordability achieved)

description: Require that the annual city budget process explicitly address HAP implementation funding. This includes: a dedicated HAP line item or program budget within the Planning Department or Community Development budget; a requirement that the City Manager's proposed budget identify which HAP actions are funded, partially funded, or unfunded in each fiscal year; and a mechanism for the HAP Implementation Committee to submit budget recommendations during the annual budget development process.
target: Budget alignment process integrated into FY2028 budget cycle (first full fiscal year after anticipated HAP adoption).
metric: HAP funding identified in annual budget (yes/no); percentage of HAP actions with dedicated funding; total annual HAP-related appropriation.
notes: Plans without budgets are wishes. This item ensures the HAP competes for resources in the annual budget process rather than being treated as an unfunded mandate on existing staff. Even modest dedicated funding ($50K-$100K annually for staffing, consulting, or program administration) signals institutional commitment. Budget alignment also forces prioritization — Council must decide which HAP items to fund first, which is the sequencing mechanism that the brainstorm itself intentionally defers.
pros: Forces the city to put resources behind HAP commitments rather than treating it as an unfunded mandate
Annual budget alignment creates a natural prioritization and sequencing mechanism
Dedicated funding line item makes HAP spending visible and accountable to taxpayers
cons: Competes with other budget priorities in a fiscally constrained environment
Dedicated housing budget may be cut in lean years, undermining implementation continuity
Budget requirement may make Council less willing to adopt the HAP in the first place

action: Land value capture and anti-speculation strategy
description: Develop a coordinated strategy to capture land value increases resulting from upzoning and public investment, and to prevent speculative land price escalation that undermines housing affordability. Tools to evaluate include: strategic land banking through a municipal acquisition fund for parcels in areas targeted for upzoning (acquire before rezoning drives prices up); enhanced use of TIF districts to capture incremental tax revenue from upzoned areas; inclusionary zoning in-lieu fees calibrated to land value increases; and monitoring of land transaction prices in areas where zoning changes are proposed or adopted.
target: Strategy framework developed within first year of HAP adoption. Land price monitoring initiated immediately upon adoption of any major upzoning.
metric: Land transaction price trends in upzoned areas vs. citywide baseline; number of parcels acquired for housing through land banking; TIF revenue captured and deployed for housing infrastructure.
notes: This is a structural gap identified in reviewer feedback. Upzoning without land value capture mechanisms risks a scenario where land prices rise faster than housing gets built — the zoning reform enriches landowners without producing affordable units. Portsmouth's compact geography and high land values make this risk particularly acute. The strategy should be developed in coordination with the fiscal impact analysis and buildout capacity modeling.
pros: Prevents upzoning from primarily benefiting land speculators rather than producing housing
Land banking acquires parcels at pre-upzoning prices, dramatically reducing future housing development costs
Creates a self-reinforcing cycle: public investment increases land values, captured value funds more housing investment
cons: Land banking requires significant upfront capital that the city may not have
Land value capture mechanisms may face legal challenges under NH property rights framework

action: Development feasibility and pro forma analysis (2026 market conditions)
description: Commission or conduct updated development feasibility analysis reflecting 2026 market conditions — construction costs, interest rates, insurance premiums, and material costs have shifted materially since the 2022 RKG Housing Market Study. Analysis should include: pro forma modeling for representative housing types (ADU, duplex, small multifamily, large multifamily) under current cost and financing conditions; break-even rent and sale price estimates for each type; sensitivity analysis showing how feasibility changes under different incentive scenarios (tax relief, fee waivers, density bonuses); and identification of the affordability floor — the lowest rent or sale price achievable without deep subsidy under current conditions. Byron Matto's GIS analysis provides critical baseline data: current land allocation (85.8% SF-only vs. 14.2% MF-allowed), zone-specific lot size compliance rates, revenue density comparisons ($5.9M vs. $1.0M per acre), and infrastructure cost differentials. His zone-specific reform proposals (R zone to 1-acre, SRA to 15,000 sf, SRB to 7,500 sf minimums with graduated use allowances) provide concrete scenarios for modeling reformed capacity against the 3,124-unit RKG demand projection.
target: Updated feasibility analysis completed within 6 months of HAP adoption. Refreshed every 2 years or when market conditions shift significantly.
metric: Break-even rent estimates by housing type; gap between break-even rents and target AMI affordability levels; number of incentive scenarios modeled.
notes: Without current feasibility data, incentives may be miscalibrated — too small to change developer behavior, or too generous relative to actual need. This analysis is distinct from the housing gap analysis (#113), which measures demand. Feasibility analysis measures what can actually get built and at what price point under current conditions. The two together connect need to deliverability.
sources: Reviewer feedback (2026); Progress Portsmouth (2026); Byron Matto GIS analysis (Jan 2026)
pros: Calibrates incentives to actual development economics rather than assumptions from 2022
Break-even rent analysis shows exactly where the affordability gap is and how large the subsidy needs to be
Sensitivity analysis lets policymakers see which incentive levers have the most impact per dollar
cons: Pro forma analysis requires developer input and market data that may be proprietary or contested
Results become outdated quickly in volatile cost environments — requires regular updating
Analysis may show that some housing types are simply infeasible without deep subsidy, which could discourage action

action: Buildout capacity modeling (current vs. reformed zoning)
description: Model the theoretical and realistic housing production capacity under current zoning versus proposed zoning reforms. Analysis should show: current by-right theoretical capacity (how many units could be built today under existing zoning without variances); realistic capacity (adjusted for site constraints, owner willingness, market absorption, and development probability); reformed capacity (theoretical and realistic unit yields under proposed zoning changes from the HAP); and the gap between reformed capacity and the RKG demand projection of 3,124 units. Builds on Byron Matto's GIS parcel analysis for ADUs and conversions.
target: Initial buildout model completed within 6 months of HAP adoption. Updated as zoning reforms are adopted.
metric: Theoretical vs. realistic unit capacity under current zoning; theoretical vs. realistic capacity under reformed zoning; gap to 3,124-unit demand projection; estimated years to close gap at projected absorption rates.
notes: This is the analytical bridge between zoning reform proposals and production targets. Without it, AMI-calibrated targets and vacancy rate goals float unanchored — there is no way to evaluate whether proposed reforms are sufficient to meet documented need. The model should be visual (maps showing where capacity exists) and should explicitly show the gap between what zoning allows and what the market is likely to deliver. GIS partnership with Byron Matto and potentially UNH (#76) is the natural vehicle.
pros: Connects zoning reform proposals directly to unit production estimates — makes the case for reform concrete.
Visual gap analysis makes housing capacity and demand data accessible for public and Council review.
Realistic capacity adjustments prevent overpromising what zoning changes alone can deliver.
cons: Modeling requires assumptions about owner willingness and market absorption that are inherently uncertain
Theoretical capacity numbers can be misleadingly large — critics may argue reforms aren't needed if current zoning already allows thousands of units
Parcel-level analysis may identify politically sensitive sites, creating opposition before reforms are even proposed

pros: Provides early warning of shifts in housing utilization and ownership patterns that may reduce effective year-round supply.
Supports data-driven decision-making rather than reactive policy debates.
Improves transparency around market structure and long-term housing trends.
Helps distinguish between supply constraints and ownership concentration trends.
Aligns with production targets by ensuring new units are functioning as intended in the year-round housing market.
cons: Data collection may be imperfect or require cross-department coordination.
Monitoring does not by itself increase housing supply.
Risk of misinterpretation if indicators are viewed without context.
Could generate political pressure for policy responses before trends are fully established.
Some ownership or utilization data may be difficult to access or verify.
